Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Molecular-genetic Basis of Parallel Adaptation Driven by Coevolutionary Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Newts defend themselves from predators such as snakes by secreting a potent nerve poison, tetrodotoxin (TTX), but some populations and species of garter snakes have evolved resistance to TTX. The molecular mechanism for this resistance is known, as is one of the genes involved, providing an excellent opportunity to investigate the evolutionary genetics of a trait that has a clear adaptive value. The studies will include a survey of the genetic differences underlying the variation in resistance to TTX in different populations and species of garter snakes and a molecular genetic evaluation of the role of natural selection in the evolution of resistance. Several factors could underlie the presence of resistance in multiple populations. These are multiple episodes of independent evolution, spread across populations, or shared ancestry; these alternatives will be tested with molecular genetic analyses. The research will result in disentangling the role of novel mutations, recombination, and gene flow in explaining the geographic patterns of phenotypic diversity.

This project will help to support graduate and undergraduate education in behavioral and molecular genetics. The PIs will promote the participation of minorities and women in science careers through the Utash State University NSF ADVANCE program, the USU Multicultural Research Fellowship Program, and the Mountain Lake Biological Station REU program. The snake-newt system will continue to be developed as a model to illustrate the evolutionary process to the general public through outreach education (similar to the recent PBS-TV material and articles in popular media) and exhibits in museums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Voltage-gated sodium channels (VGSC) are a critical component of the vertebrate nervous system that allows electrical impulses to transmit along nerves and muscles. If their function is impaired, either through mutations to the protein or by toxins in the environment, the effects are often lethal. The study of a natural predator-prey arms race in which predators (snakes) must evolve to their toxic prey (newts) provides insights into both the structure and function of these channels, and also into the fundamental process of evolution. The major goal of this project was to reveal the process of adaptation at the molecular level by investigating parallel evolution in the family of VGSC in snakes.

Results of this work demonstrate that evolutionary changes in the VGSC proteins confer resistance to a deadly neurotoxin, tetrodoxin (TTX) that normally blocks VGSC. In snakes that have evolved with TTX-bearing prey, VGSC in muscles have evolved the same few changes all over the world. These results present evidence for the minority view that evolution proceeds through few mutations of relatively large effect to functional genes, as opposed to alterations of expression patterns. The fact that similar or even identical genetic changes have occurred in multiple species suggests that the process of adaptation at the molecular level is more predictable and repeatable than previously assumed.

Further work shows that a similar process of convergence occurs among paralogs within a family of genes expressed in different tissues of the same organism. Previous investigations focused on the same gene in many species, but our work suggests the same processes shape the evolution of paralogous proteins within a species. In other words, the process of adaptation is consistent whether across species around the world, or among genes expressed within the same body. The implication is that evolution might be much more predictable than previous thought, when enough is known about the functional constraints faced by proteins.

Together, the work builds an unprecedented link between the ecological forces that drive arms races between natural enemies and the molecular genetic mechanisms that underlie the resultant evolution.

Through the research conducted during this award, two postodoctoral fellows and 3 graduate students were supported. Many undergraduates assisted with the project in laboratory or field contexts, gaining experience in the basic process of research, laboratory bench skills, and field biology techniques.

The snake-newt system is one of the best-known examples of co-evolution at the molecular level, appearing in numerous textbooks and popular media. The research plays a significant role in public talks, demonstrations and “show-and-tell” events to K-12 groups, visiting natural history clubs, and open houses. As such, it is a significant contributor to public science literacy.
